 I would say that we should not blame the sword for the hand that wields it. 
 
 What we should do instead is hold those who are a fault accountable—the person who chose to commit a wrongful act through an unjustifiable motive, be it anger, hatred, revenge, greed, etc. 
 
 We should seek to hold accountable the person who knew right from wrong, who understood the nature and consequences of his actions, and who made a conscious choice to take someone’s life without a shred of legitimate excuse or justification. 
 
 This is how we should respond to murder.
 
 In doing so I would also suggest that we do not direct any anger at a suspect. Being angry is one thing, reacting through anger is entirely another. Giving reign to our anger or frustration serves only to tempt us to rush forward through a process in which we substitute the goal of vengeance for principle of justice. Two eyes for an eye and a heart for a tooth cannot be our motto.
 
 These are not new or novel concepts. They have formed the foundation of our system of criminal justice for more than two centuries.
